hints.content:
608: :label: axiom-guaranteed-revival
609:

hints.label: thm-revival-guarantee
hints.title: Almost‑sure revival under the global constraint
hints.content:
623: :::{prf:theorem} Almost‑sure revival under the global constraint
624: :label: thm-revival-guarantee
625: Assume the global constraint $\varepsilon_{\text{clone}}\,p_{\max} < \eta^{\alpha+\beta}$. Let $\mathcal S$ be any swarm with at least one alive walker ($|\mathcal A(\mathcal S)|\ge 1$) and let $i\in\mathcal D(\mathcal S)$ be dead. Then, under the cloning rule with threshold $T_{\text{clone}}\sim\mathrm{Unif}(0,p_{\max})$ and a per‑dead‑walker score $S_i$ computed from an alive companion as in §16.1, we have
626: 
627: $$
628: \mathbb P\big[\text{$i$ is revived in the cloning stage}\big] \;=\;1.
629: $$
630: 
631: In particular, $S_i > p_{\max}$ surely, hence $S_i > T_{\text{clone}}$ for every threshold realization. The conclusion holds also when $|\mathcal A(\mathcal S)|=1$ (single‑survivor case) since the companion selection measure assigns the unique alive index to every dead walker (cf. [](#def-companion-selection-measure)).

hints.label: proof-thm-revival-guarantee
hints.content:
639: :::{prf:proof}
640: :label: proof-thm-revival-guarantee
641: Let $j\in\mathcal A(\mathcal S)$ be any alive companion. By construction of the fitness potential with rescale floor $\eta$ and weights $(\alpha,\beta)$, we have $V_{\text{fit},j} \ge \eta^{\alpha+\beta}$. The cloning score of a dead walker $i$ satisfies the lower bound
642: 
643: $$
644: S_i \;\ge\; \frac{V_{\text{fit},j}}{\varepsilon_{\text{clone}}} \;\ge\; \frac{\eta^{\alpha+\beta}}{\varepsilon_{\text{clone}}}.
645: $$
646: 
647: By the stated constraint, $\eta^{\alpha+\beta}/\varepsilon_{\text{clone}} > p_{\max}$, hence deterministically $S_i>p_{\max}$. Since $T_{\text{clone}}\in[0,p_{\max}]$, we have $S_i>T_{\text{clone}}$ for every threshold draw, so $i$ is cloned with probability one. When $|\mathcal A(\mathcal S)|=1$, the companion of every dead walker is the unique alive index by [](#def-companion-selection-measure), and the same bound applies. This proves the claim.

hints.label: axiom-boundary-regularity
hints.title: Axiom of Boundary Regularity
hints.content:
675: :label: axiom-boundary-regularity
676: 
677: *   **Core Assumption:** The marginal probability of a single walker becoming invalid after the perturbation and status update stages must be a smooth (Hölder continuous) function of the initial N-particle swarm state. This axiom applies to any valid noise measure, including those with state-dependent coupling between walkers.
678: 
679: *   **Axiomatic Parameters:** The user must provide the constants that bound this relationship, derived from their choice of **Noise Measure**, **Valid Domain**, and **Projection Map**:
680:     1.  **$L_{\text{death}}$ > 0 (The Boundary Instability Factor):** The Hölder constant for the marginal death probability function.
681:     2.  **$\alpha_B$ ∈ (0, 1] (The Boundary Smoothing Exponent):** The Hölder exponent.
682: 
683: *   **Condition:** Let $P(s_{\text{out},i}=0 | \mathcal{S})$ be the marginal probability that walker $i$ has a status of 0 after the application of the composed operator $\Psi_{\text{status}} \circ \Psi_{\text{pert}}$ to an initial swarm state $\mathcal{S}$. These constants must satisfy the following inequality for any two swarm states $\mathcal{S}_1, \mathcal{S}_2 \in \Sigma_N$ and for all walkers $i \in \{1, \dots, N\}$:
684: 
685: 
686: 
687: $$
688: |P(s_{\text{out},i}=0 | \mathcal{S}_1) - P(s_{\text{out},i}=0 | \mathcal{S}_2)| \le L_{\text{death}} \cdot d_{\text{Disp},\mathcal{Y}}(\mathcal{S}_1, \mathcal{S}_2)^{\alpha_B}
689: $$
690: 
691: *   **Canonical Bounds:** When the invalid set has finite perimeter and the perturbation kernel satisfies the smoothness assumptions below, we may take explicit constants:
692:     - **Uniform ball kernels.** Section 4.2.3 shows that for $\mathcal P_\sigma(x,\cdot)$ uniform on $B(x,\sigma)$ the death probability is Lipschitz with constant $L_{\text{death}} \le C_d\,\mathrm{Per}(\mathcal X_{\mathrm{invalid}})/\sigma$ and exponent $\alpha_B=1$ ([](#lem-boundary-uniform-ball)).
693:     - **Gaussian/heat kernels.** Section 4.2.4 proves the analogous bound $L_{\text{death}} \le C'_d\,\mathrm{Per}(\mathcal X_{\mathrm{invalid}})/\sigma$ with $\alpha_B=1$ by convolution with the heat kernel ([](#lem-boundary-heat-kernel))).
694:     - **Projections.** If a nontrivial projection $\varphi$ is used, include the distortion factor from its Lipschitz constant as discussed after these lemmas.
695: 
696: *   **Failure Mode Analysis:** A large **$L_{\text{death}}$** indicates a "sharp" or unpredictable boundary in the N-particle state space. A small change in the overall swarm's configuration (either a small shift in walker positions or a single status change) could lead to a drastic change in a walker's individual survival probability. This makes the swarm's behavior near the boundary highly unstable and risks unexpected, large-scale death events that are not well-correlated with the simple displacement of individual walkers.
697:

hints.label: axiom-boundary-smoothness
hints.title: Axiom of Boundary Smoothness
hints.content:
713: :label: axiom-boundary-smoothness
714: 
715: *   **Core Assumption:** The boundary of the valid domain, $\partial \mathcal{X}_{\mathrm{valid}}$, must be a $(d-1)$‑dimensional continuously differentiable ($C^1$) submanifold of the $d$‑dimensional state space $\mathcal{X}$.
716: 
717: *   **Rationale:** This is the standard condition in geometric measure theory ensuring the boundary has Lebesgue measure zero in the ambient space. It is a critical prerequisite for proving that $\partial \mathcal{X}_{\mathrm{valid}}$ is a null set for any absolutely continuous perturbation kernel, which is a key step in validating the **Axiom of Boundary Regularity**.
718: 
719: *   **Framework Application:** This axiom serves as the formal prerequisite for establishing that the integral defining the death probability is a continuous function of the swarm state, thereby supporting the **Axiom of Boundary Regularity** ([](#axiom-boundary-regularity)).
720:
hints.section: ## 3. Axiomatic Foundations: A Parametric Debugging Framework
hints.raw_directive:
710: :::
711: 
712: :::{prf:axiom} Axiom of Boundary Smoothness
713: :label: axiom-boundary-smoothness
714: 
715: *   **Core Assumption:** The boundary of the valid domain, $\partial \mathcal{X}_{\mathrm{valid}}$, must be a $(d-1)$‑dimensional continuously differentiable ($C^1$) submanifold of the $d$‑dimensional state space $\mathcal{X}$.
716: 
717: *   **Rationale:** This is the standard condition in geometric measure theory ensuring the boundary has Lebesgue measure zero in the ambient space. It is a critical prerequisite for proving that $\partial \mathcal{X}_{\mathrm{valid}}$ is a null set for any absolutely continuous perturbation kernel, which is a key step in validating the **Axiom of Boundary Regularity**.
718: 
719: *   **Framework Application:** This axiom serves as the formal prerequisite for establishing that the integral defining the death probability is a continuous function of the swarm state, thereby supporting the **Axiom of Boundary Regularity** ([](#axiom-boundary-regularity)).
720: 
721: *   **Failure Mode Analysis:** If the boundary is not a $C^1$ submanifold (e.g., fractal or space‑filling), it may have positive Lebesgue measure. Then the probability of a walker landing exactly on the boundary can be non‑zero, the death‑probability function may fail to be continuous, and the continuity analysis of the swarm update operator breaks down.

hints.label: axiom-environmental-richness
hints.title: Axiom of Environmental Richness
hints.content:
750: :label: axiom-environmental-richness
751: 
752: *   **Core Assumption:** The reward function $R$ must not be pathologically flat at a user-defined minimum length scale. The algorithm requires a guaranteed level of reward variation to learn.
753: *   **Axiomatic Parameters:** The user must provide two parameters that quantify the learnability of the reward landscape:
754:     1.  **$r_{\min}$ > 0 (The Minimum Richness Scale):** The minimum radius in the algorithmic space above which the reward function is guaranteed to exhibit variance. This parameter quantifies the resolution at which the user expects to find a learnable signal.
755:     2.  **$\kappa_{\text{richness}}$ (The Environmental Richness Floor):** A value that acts as a guaranteed lower bound on the variance of the reward function within any localized region of the projected valid domain *with a radius greater than or equal to $r_{\min}$*.
756: 
757: *   **Condition:** The user must choose $r_{\min}$ and determine $\kappa_{\text{richness}}$ such that they satisfy the following inequality, which formally links the two parameters:
758: 
759: 
760: 
761: $$
762: \kappa_{\text{richness}} \le \inf_{y \in \varphi(\mathcal{X}_{\mathrm{valid}}), r \ge r_{\min}} \left( \text{Var}_{y' \in B(y,r) \cap \varphi(\mathcal{X}_{\mathrm{valid}})} [R_{\mathcal{Y}}(y')] \right)
763: $$
764:

753: *   **Axiomatic Parameters:** The user must provide two parameters that quantify the learnability of the reward landscape:
754:     1.  **$r_{\min}$ > 0 (The Minimum Richness Scale):** The minimum radius in the algorithmic space above which the reward function is guaranteed to exhibit variance. This parameter quantifies the resolution at which the user expects to find a learnable signal.
755:     2.  **$\kappa_{\text{richness}}$ (The Environmental Richness Floor):** A value that acts as a guaranteed lower bound on the variance of the reward function within any localized region of the projected valid domain *with a radius greater than or equal to $r_{\min}$*.
756: 
757: *   **Condition:** The user must choose $r_{\min}$ and determine $\kappa_{\text{richness}}$ such that they satisfy the following inequality, which formally links the two parameters:
758: 
759:

761: $$
762: \kappa_{\text{richness}} \le \inf_{y \in \varphi(\mathcal{X}_{\mathrm{valid}}), r \ge r_{\min}} \left( \text{Var}_{y' \in B(y,r) \cap \varphi(\mathcal{X}_{\mathrm{valid}})} [R_{\mathcal{Y}}(y')] \right)

hints.label: axiom-reward-regularity
hints.title: Axiom of Reward Regularity
hints.content:
776: :label: axiom-reward-regularity
777: 
778: *   **Core Assumption:** The reward function, when viewed in the algorithmic space, must be Hölder continuous.
779: 
780: *   **Axiomatic Parameters:** The user must provide the constants that bound the reward function's smoothness:
781:     1.  **$L_{R,\mathcal{Y}} > 0$ (The Reward Volatility Factor):** The Hölder constant of the reward function in the algorithmic space.
782:     2.  **$\alpha_R \in (0, 1]$ (The Reward Smoothing Exponent):** The Hölder exponent for the reward function on $(\mathcal{Y},d_{\mathcal{Y}})$.
783: 
784: *   **Condition:** These constants must satisfy, for any $y_1, y_2 \in \mathcal{Y}$,
785: 
786: 
787: $$
788: |R_{\mathcal{Y}}(y_1) - R_{\mathcal{Y}}(y_2)| \le L_{R,\mathcal{Y}} \cdot d_{\mathcal{Y}}(y_1, y_2)^{\alpha_R}.
789: $$
790: 
791: *   **Failure Mode Analysis:** A large **$L_{R,\mathcal{Y}}$** signifies a "bumpy" or volatile reward landscape. This can cause the exploitation component of the fitness potential to fluctuate wildly with small movements, making cloning decisions noisy and potentially unstable.

hints.label: def-valid-noise-measure
hints.title: Valid Noise Measure
hints.content:
836: :::{prf:definition} Valid Noise Measure
837: :label: def-valid-noise-measure
838: A kernel $\mathcal P_\sigma$ (and analogously $\mathcal Q_\delta$) is valid if it is Feller and satisfies:
839: - Bounded second moment in $\mathcal Y$ with constant $M_{\mathrm{pert}}^2$ (as used in the perturbation continuity bounds);
840: - Boundary regularity assumptions required by the status‑continuity theorem (Section 14);
841: - Non‑degeneracy as stipulated where needed.
842: This consolidates the standing noise requirements referenced elsewhere in the framework.

hints.label: axiom-non-degenerate-noise
hints.title: Axiom of Non-Degenerate Noise
hints.content:
874: :label: axiom-non-degenerate-noise
875: 
876: *   **Core Assumption:** The **Perturbation** and **Cloning** measures must not be the Dirac delta measure.
877: *   **Axiomatic Parameters ($\sigma$, $\delta$ - The Noise Scales):** The user provides these parameters directly.
hints.section: ## 3. Axiomatic Foundations: A Parametric Debugging Framework
hints.raw_directive:
871: The swarm relies on noise to explore the state space and prevent collapsing to a single point.
872: 
873: :::{prf:axiom} Axiom of Non-Degenerate Noise
874: :label: axiom-non-degenerate-noise
875: 
876: *   **Core Assumption:** The **Perturbation** and **Cloning** measures must not be the Dirac delta measure.
877: *   **Axiomatic Parameters ($\sigma$, $\delta$ - The Noise Scales):** The user provides these parameters directly.
878: *   **Condition:** The user must ensure **$\sigma > 0$** and **$\delta > 0$**.

889: :label: def-components-mean-square-standardization-error

This component quantifies the propagation of measurement stochasticity.

hints.label: thm-mean-square-standardization-error
hints.title: Asymptotic Behavior of the Mean-Square Standardization Error
hints.content:
901: :label: thm-mean-square-standardization-error
902: 
903: The continuity of the **N-Dimensional Standardization Operator** $z(\mathcal{S})$ depends on the coupled effects of two distinct error sources whose expected growth rates are summed.
904: 
905: *   **Core Principle:** The total **expected** squared error in the standardization operator's output, $\mathbb{E}[\| \mathbf{z}_1 - \mathbf{z}_2 \|_2^2]$, is bounded by the sum of the **Expected Squared Value Error** ($E^2_{V,ms}$) and the **Expected Squared Structural Error** ($E^2_{S,ms}$).
906: 
907: *   **Mathematical Result (General Form):** For a large number of alive walkers, $k_1 = |\mathcal{A}(\mathcal{S}_1)|$, the total expected error has an asymptotic growth rate given by the sum of the growth rates of its two components:
908: 
909: 
910: 
911: $$
912: \boxed{
913:     \mathbb{E}[\| \mathbf{z}_1 - \mathbf{z}_2 \|_2^2] \in O(E_{V,ms}^2(k_1)) + O(E_{S,ms}^2(k_1))
914:     }
915: $$
916: 
917: *   **Implications & Failure Modes:** The overall mean-square continuity of the standardization pipeline is governed by the operational regime of the swarm. The analysis reveals a critical distinction between normal operation and catastrophic collapse.
hints.section: ## 3. Axiomatic Foundations: A Parametric Debugging Framework
hints.raw_directive:
898: The following theorem, which is a key result of the analysis in Section 11, establishes the asymptotic behavior of these error components.
899: 
900: :::{prf:theorem} Asymptotic Behavior of the Mean-Square Standardization Error
901: :label: thm-mean-square-standardization-error
902: 
903: The continuity of the **N-Dimensional Standardization Operator** $z(\mathcal{S})$ depends on the coupled effects of two distinct error sources whose expected growth rates are summed.
904: 
905: *   **Core Principle:** The total **expected** squared error in the standardization operator's output, $\mathbb{E}[\| \mathbf{z}_1 - \mathbf{z}_2 \|_2^2]$, is bounded by the sum of the **Expected Squared Value Error** ($E^2_{V,ms}$) and the **Expected Squared Structural Error** ($E^2_{S,ms}$).
906: 
907: *   **Mathematical Result (General Form):** For a large number of alive walkers, $k_1 = |\mathcal{A}(\mathcal{S}_1)|$, the total expected error has an asymptotic growth rate given by the sum of the growth rates of its two components:
908: 
909: 
910: 
911: $$
912: \boxed{
913:     \mathbb{E}[\| \mathbf{z}_1 - \mathbf{z}_2 \|_2^2] \in O(E_{V,ms}^2(k_1)) + O(E_{S,ms}^2(k_1))
914:     }
915: $$
916: 
917: *   **Implications & Failure Modes:** The overall mean-square continuity of the standardization pipeline is governed by the operational regime of the swarm. The analysis reveals a critical distinction between normal operation and catastrophic collapse.
918:     1.  **Regime 1: Normal Operation (Asymptotically Stable):** Under normal conditions where walker attrition is low and the number of status changes ($n_c$) is small, the structural error term is negligible. The dominant error is the **expected value error**, which, for the benchmark case of an empirical aggregator and distance-to-companion measurement, **is constant with respect to swarm size** ($E^2_{V,ms} \in O(1)$). This is a powerful result, indicating that under stable conditions, the algorithm's average measurement process **does not become noisier as the swarm gets larger**. The primary bottleneck for stability in this regime is not swarm size but the **extreme sensitivity to the regularization parameter**, as all error sources are amplified by a factor of up to **$O(\varepsilon_{\text{std}}^{-6})$**.

hints.label: axiom-bounded-relative-collapse
hints.title: Axiom of Bounded Relative Collapse
hints.content:
927: :label: axiom-bounded-relative-collapse
928: 
929: *   **Core Assumption:** The scaling analysis for structural error is valid only for transitions that are not catastrophically large relative to the initial swarm size.
930: *   **Axiomatic Parameter ($c_{\min}$ - The Relative Collapse Tolerance):** The user must provide a constant $c_{\min} \in (0, 1]$ that defines the minimum fraction of the swarm that must survive a transition for the structural growth exponent analysis to be considered valid.
931: *   **Condition:** A transition from a swarm $S_1$ to $S_2$ is considered **non-catastrophic** if it satisfies:
932: 
933: $$
934: \frac{|\mathcal{A}(\mathcal{S}_2)|}{|\mathcal{A}(\mathcal{S}_1)|} \ge c_{\min}
935: $$
hints.section: ## 3. Axiomatic Foundations: A Parametric Debugging Framework
hints.raw_directive:
924: For the framework's stability analysis to be sound, any chosen aggregation operator must satisfy the following axioms, and the user must provide the corresponding axiomatic parameters.

927: :label: axiom-bounded-relative-collapse

930: *   **Axiomatic Parameter ($c_{\min}$ - The Relative Collapse Tolerance):** The user must provide a constant $c_{\min} \in (0, 1]$ that defines the minimum fraction of the swarm that must survive a transition for the structural growth exponent analysis to be considered valid.
931: *   **Condition:** A transition from a swarm $S_1$ to $S_2$ is considered **non-catastrophic** if it satisfies:
932: 
933: $$
934: \frac{|\mathcal{A}(\mathcal{S}_2)|}{|\mathcal{A}(\mathcal{S}_1)|} \ge c_{\min}
935: $$

hints.label: axiom-bounded-deviation-variance
hints.title: Axiom of Bounded Deviation from Aggregated Variance
hints.content:
941: :label: axiom-bounded-deviation-variance
942: 
943: *   **Core Assumption:** The sum of squared deviations of the raw input values from the aggregator's computed mean must be controllably related to the variance computed by the aggregator itself. This prevents aggregators from producing statistical moments that are pathologically decoupled from the input data.
944: *   **Axiomatic Parameter ($\kappa_{\text{var}}$ - The Variance Deviation Factor):** The user must provide a constant $\kappa_{\text{var}} \geq 1$ that bounds this relationship.
945: *   **Condition:** For any swarm state $S$ with alive set $A$ and any raw value vector $v_A$, the following must hold:
946: 
947: $$
948: \sum_{i \in \mathcal{A}} (v_i - \mu(\mathcal{S}, \mathbf{v}_{\mathcal{A}}))^2 \le \kappa_{\text{var}} \cdot |\mathcal{A}| \cdot \text{Var}[M(\mathcal{S}, \mathbf{v}_{\mathcal{A}})]
949: $$
950: 
951: where $\text{Var}[M]$ is the variance of the aggregator's output measure.

hints.label: axiom-bounded-variance-production
hints.title: Axiom of Bounded Variance Production
hints.content:
957: :label: axiom-bounded-variance-production
958: 
959: *   **Core Assumption:** The variance of the measure produced by the aggregation operator must itself be bounded by a function of the input value range. This prevents an aggregator from creating arbitrarily large variance from bounded inputs.
960: *   **Axiomatic Parameter ($\kappa_{\text{range}}$ - The Range-to-Variance Factor):** The user must provide a constant $\kappa_{\text{range}} \geq 0$.
961: *   **Condition:** For any swarm $S$ and any value vector $v$ with components bounded by $V_{\max}$, the aggregator $M$ must satisfy:
962: 
963: $$
964: \text{Var}[M(\mathcal{S}, \mathbf{v})] \le \kappa_{\text{range}} \cdot V_{\max}^2
965: $$

hints.label: axiom-geometric-consistency
hints.title: Axiom of Geometric Consistency
hints.content:
977: :label: axiom-geometric-consistency
978: 
979: *   **Core Assumption:** The algorithmic noise should be unbiased and isotropic, unless intentionally designed otherwise.
980: *   **Axiomatic Parameters (Practical Proxies):**
981:     1.  **$\kappa_{\text{drift}}$ (Anomalous Drift):** The maximum magnitude of any local drift introduced by the noise measure:
982: 
983: 
984: 
985: $$
986: \kappa_{\text{drift}} := \sup_{x \in \mathcal{X}} \|\mathbb{E}_{x' \sim \mathcal{P}_\sigma(x, \cdot)}[x' - x]\|
987: $$
988: 
989:     2.  **$\kappa_{\text{anisotropy}}$ (Diffusion Anisotropy):** The maximum condition number of the displacement's covariance matrix:
990: 
991: 
992: 
993: $$
994: \kappa_{\text{anisotropy}} := \sup_{x \in \mathcal{X}} \frac{\lambda_{\max}(\text{Cov}_{x' \sim \mathcal{P}_\sigma(x, \cdot)}[x'])}{\lambda_{\min}(\text{Cov}_{x' \sim \mathcal{P}_\sigma(x, \cdot)}[x'])}
995: $$
996:

980: *   **Axiomatic Parameters (Practical Proxies):**

982:

986: \kappa_{\text{drift}} := \sup_{x \in \mathcal{X}} \|\mathbb{E}_{x' \sim \mathcal{P}_\sigma(x, \cdot)}[x' - x]\|
987: $$
988: 
989:     2.  **$\kappa_{\text{anisotropy}}$ (Diffusion Anisotropy):** The maximum condition number of the displacement's covariance matrix:
990: 
991: 
992: 
993: $$
994: \kappa_{\text{anisotropy}} := \sup_{x \in \mathcal{X}} \frac{\lambda_{\max}(\text{Cov}_{x' \sim \mathcal{P}_\sigma(x, \cdot)}[x'])}{\lambda_{\min}(\text{Cov}_{x' \sim \mathcal{P}_\sigma(x, \cdot)}[x'])}

hints.label: thm-forced-activity
hints.title: Theorem of Forced Activity
hints.content:
1009: :class: important
1010: :open:
1011: This theorem is beautiful because it guarantees the swarm can never get completely stuck! Here's the intuition:
1012: 
1013: **The Setup**: If you have:
1014: 1. **Spread out walkers** (covering enough space to sense reward differences)
1015: 2. **Rich environment** (reward actually varies across space)
1016: 3. **Non-zero amplification** (the algorithm pays attention to rewards)
1017: 4. **Some noise** (walkers can explore)
1018: 
1019: **The Conclusion**: Then some cloning MUST happen - the swarm can't just sit still.
1020: 
1021: **Why it works**: Spread-out walkers in a rich environment will experience different rewards. This creates fitness differences. With amplification > 0, these differences get magnified into different cloning probabilities. Someone will always be "fit enough" to clone, keeping the swarm active.
hints.section: ## 3. Axiomatic Foundations: A Parametric Debugging Framework
hints.raw_directive:
1003: For the algorithm's adaptive and contractive forces to function, a swarm that is not collapsed to a single point must generate a non-zero probability of cloning. This is the engine of adaptation.
1004: 
1005: :::{prf:theorem} Theorem of Forced Activity
1006: :label: thm-forced-activity
1007: 
1008: :::{admonition} The "No Stagnation" Guarantee
1009: :class: important
1010: :open:
1011: This theorem is beautiful because it guarantees the swarm can never get completely stuck! Here's the intuition:
1012: 
1013: **The Setup**: If you have:
1014: 1. **Spread out walkers** (covering enough space to sense reward differences)
1015: 2. **Rich environment** (reward actually varies across space)
1016: 3. **Non-zero amplification** (the algorithm pays attention to rewards)
1017: 4. **Some noise** (walkers can explore)
1018: 
1019: **The Conclusion**: Then some cloning MUST happen - the swarm can't just sit still.
1020: 
1021: **Why it works**: Spread-out walkers in a rich environment will experience different rewards. This creates fitness differences. With amplification > 0, these differences get magnified into different cloning probabilities. Someone will always be "fit enough" to clone, keeping the swarm active.
1022:

hints.label: axiom-margin-stability
hints.title: Axiom of Position‑Only Status Margin
hints.content:
1079: :::{prf:axiom} Axiom of Position‑Only Status Margin
1080: :label: axiom-margin-stability
1081: There exists a uniform margin $r_{\mathrm{pos}}>0$ such that for any two swarms $\mathcal{S}_1,\mathcal{S}_2\in\Sigma_N$ with
1082: 
1083: $$
1084: \frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^N d_{\mathcal Y}\!\big(\varphi(x_{1,i}),\varphi(x_{2,i})\big)^2\;\le\; r_{\mathrm{pos}},
1085: $$
1086: 
1087: the alive/dead decisions are invariant under the status update:
1088: 
1089: $$
1090: n_c(\mathcal{S}_1,\mathcal{S}_2)=0.
1091: $$

hints.label: rem-margin-stability
hints.content:
1096: :::{prf:remark}
1097: :label: rem-margin-stability
1098: This axiom expresses a deterministic stability of the status update in terms of the positional component alone. It is strictly stronger than the trivial consequence of the identity
1099: 
1100: $$
1101: d_{\text{Disp},\mathcal{Y}}(\mathcal{S}_1,\mathcal{S}_2)^2 = \tfrac{1}{N}\,\Delta_{\text{pos}}^2 + \tfrac{\lambda_{\mathrm{status}}}{N}\,n_c,
1102: $$
1103: 
1104: which would otherwise allow a tautological “margin” by tuning $\lambda_{\mathrm{status}}$.
1105: n_c\;\le\; \frac{N}{\lambda_{\mathrm{status}}}\, d_{\text{Disp},\mathcal{Y}}(\mathcal{S}_1,\mathcal{S}_2)^2,\qquad
1106: n_c^2\;\le\; \left(\frac{N}{\lambda_{\mathrm{status}}}\right)^2 d_{\text{Disp},\mathcal{Y}}(\mathcal{S}_1,\mathcal{S}_2)^4.
1107:
